title: What is the purpose of default value in context?
content: The `defaultValue` argument in `React.createContext(defaultValue)` is only used when a component does not have a matching Provider above it in the tree. This is helpful for testing components in isolation.
explanation: The default value allows components to work without a Provider, which is useful in unit tests or when the Provider is conditionally rendered.
sampleAnswers: The default value in `createContext()` is used only when no Provider is present in the ancestry—ideal for testing or fallback behavior.
Example: `const ThemeContext = React.createContext('light');` ensures components render with 'light' theme if no Provider wraps them.

title: What is diffing algorithm?
content: React uses a heuristic O(n) diffing algorithm to efficiently update the UI by minimizing DOM operations, based on two assumptions: (1) different element types produce different trees, (2) keys help identify stable children.
explanation: Instead of O(n³) tree comparison, React assumes stable identity via keys and type changes imply full subtree replacement.
sampleAnswers: React’s diffing algorithm is an O(n) heuristic that avoids expensive full-tree comparisons by assuming element type changes mean new subtrees and using keys to track child identity.
This optimization enables fast UI updates even with large component trees.

title: What are the rules covered by diffing algorithm?
content: Rules: (1) Different root types → full rebuild, (2) Same DOM type → update attributes only, (3) Same component type → update props and recurse, (4) Children diffed by index unless keys are used.
explanation: These rules ensure minimal DOM mutations while maintaining correctness through key-based child reconciliation.

options.text: React compares every possible node pair in O(n³) time
Different types rebuild tree; same DOM updates attrs; same component updates props; keys optimize children diffing
Keys are optional and have no performance impact
Component instances are recreated on every render

title: When do you need to use refs?
content: Use refs for: (1) managing focus/text selection/media playback, (2) triggering imperative animations, (3) integrating with third-party DOM libraries.
explanation: Refs provide a way to access DOM nodes or React elements created in the render method, bypassing typical data flow.

options.text: For focus, animations, and third-party DOM integrations

title: Must prop be named as render for render props?
content: No. Any prop that is a function used to determine what to render is a render prop—including the `children` prop.
explanation: The pattern is defined by behavior (a function that returns JSX), not the prop name. `children` as a function is common.

title: What are the problems of using render props with pure components?
content: Creating a new function inside render negates PureComponent’s shallow comparison, causing unnecessary re-renders.
explanation: Each render creates a new function instance, so shallow prop comparison fails, and the component re-renders every time.
sampleAnswers: Defining the render function inline in render creates a new reference each time, breaking PureComponent’s optimization. Define it as an instance method or use useCallback.
Solution: Move the render function outside render or memoize it to preserve referential identity.

title: What is windowing technique?
content: Windowing renders only the visible subset of a large list, reducing DOM nodes and improving performance. Libraries: react-window, react-virtualized.
explanation: Instead of rendering 10,000 list items, windowing renders only the 20 currently visible, drastically improving memory and speed.
sampleAnswers: Windowing (or virtualization) renders only the items in the viewport, recycling DOM nodes as the user scrolls—ideal for long lists or tables.
Libraries like `react-window` provide `FixedSizeList` and `VariableSizeList` components to implement this pattern easily.

title: How do you print falsy values in JSX?
content: Falsy values (false, null, undefined) don’t render in JSX. Convert them to strings using `String()` or template literals.
explanation: React ignores falsy children for convenience (e.g., `{condition && <Component />}`), but explicit conversion shows the value.
sampleAnswers: Use `{String(myVar)}` or `{`${myVar}`}` to display falsy values like `null` or `undefined` in JSX.

Example: `
Value: {String(user.age)}
` will show 'Value: null' if age is null.

title: What is the typical use case of portals?
content: Portals render modals, tooltips, dropdowns, and notifications outside the parent DOM tree to avoid CSS issues like `overflow: hidden` or `z-index` stacking contexts.
explanation: By rendering into a separate DOM node (e.g., `document.body`), portals escape parent styling constraints.

options.text: To render modals/tooltips outside parent DOM to avoid CSS clipping and z-index issues

title: How do you set default value for uncontrolled component?
content: Use `defaultValue` for text inputs and `defaultChecked` for checkboxes/radios to set initial values without controlling subsequent updates.
explanation: `defaultValue` sets the initial DOM value but doesn’t override user changes, unlike `value` which fully controls the input.
sampleAnswers: Use `<input defaultValue="John" />` to set the initial value of an uncontrolled input. For checkboxes, use `defaultChecked={true}`.
This is useful when you need to initialize a form but don’t want to manage every keystroke with state.

title: What is your favorite React stack?
content: A popular stack includes Redux/redux-saga for state, react-router for routing, styled-components for styling, axios for API calls, and webpack/Babel for tooling.
explanation: This stack balances maturity, performance, and developer experience for large-scale applications.
sampleAnswers: A robust React stack: Redux + redux-saga for state and side effects, React Router for navigation, styled-components for styling, axios for HTTP, and Webpack/Babel for builds.
Projects like react-boilerplate provide this setup out of the box for production-ready apps.

title: What is the difference between Real DOM and Virtual DOM?
content: Real DOM updates are slow and expensive; Virtual DOM is a lightweight JS representation that enables fast diffing and minimal real DOM mutations.
explanation: Virtual DOM allows React to compute the minimal set of changes before touching the real DOM, optimizing performance.

options.text: Real DOM is faster than Virtual DOM
Real DOM updates are slow/expensive; Virtual DOM enables fast, minimal updates

title: How to add Bootstrap to a React application?
content: Three ways: (1) CDN, (2) npm install bootstrap + import CSS, (3) React-specific libraries like react-bootstrap or reactstrap.
explanation: React-specific libraries (react-bootstrap) wrap Bootstrap components as React components, avoiding jQuery dependency.

options.text: CDN, npm install, or React wrappers like react-bootstrap

title: Can you list top websites using React?
content: Top sites: Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, Uber, Airbnb, Netflix, PayPal, Khan Academy, Dropbox, Flipboard.
explanation: React’s component model and performance make it ideal for large, dynamic user interfaces.
sampleAnswers: Major companies using React include Facebook (creator), Instagram, WhatsApp, Airbnb, Netflix, Uber, and PayPal.
These companies rely on React for its declarative UI, performance, and rich ecosystem.

title: Is it recommended to use CSS In JS in React?
content: React has no opinion, but beginners should start with CSS files and className. CSS-in-JS (e.g., styled-components) is a valid alternative for scoped styles.
explanation: CSS-in-JS offers benefits like dynamic styling and scoping, but traditional CSS is simpler for beginners.

title: Do I need to rewrite all my class components with hooks?
content: No. Hooks are additive; you can use them in new components without rewriting existing class components.
explanation: React has no plans to remove class components. Hooks and classes can coexist in the same app.

title: What is useEffect hook? How to fetch data with React Hooks?
content: `useEffect` handles side effects in function components. Use it with `useState` to fetch data on mount by passing an empty dependency array.
explanation: It replaces componentDidMount, componentDidUpdate, and componentWillUnmount with a unified API.
sampleAnswers: `useEffect(() => { fetch(url).then(setData); }, []);` fetches data once on mount. The empty array ensures it doesn’t re-run on updates.
Always include cleanup for subscriptions or async operations to avoid memory leaks or state updates on unmounted components.

title: Is Hooks cover all use cases for classes?
content: Not yet. Hooks don’t cover `getSnapshotBeforeUpdate` and `componentDidCatch` (error boundaries).
explanation: Error boundaries and snapshot reading are still class-only features, though the React team plans to add Hook equivalents.

title: What is the stable release for hooks support?
content: React 16.8 introduced stable Hooks support for React DOM, React DOM Server, React Test Renderer, and React Shallow Renderer.
explanation: React 16.8 (February 2019) was the first version to include Hooks as a stable feature.
sampleAnswers: React 16.8, released in February 2019, was the first stable version to include Hooks across all official React packages.
This allowed function components to use state and side effects without classes.

title: Why do we use array destructuring in `useState`?
content: `useState` returns an array `[value, setValue]`. Destructuring makes it clear and concise: `const [count, setCount] = useState(0)`.
explanation: Array destructuring provides semantic names for the state value and updater function, improving readability.
sampleAnswers: Instead of `const state = useState(0); const count = state[0]; const setCount = state[1];`, we write `const [count, setCount] = useState(0);` for clarity.
This pattern is idiomatic in React and makes state usage self-documenting.

title: What are the sources used for introducing hooks?
content: Hooks drew inspiration from: react-future experiments, render props (Reactions Component), DisplayScript state cells, Rx subscriptions, and ReasonReact reducer components.
explanation: Hooks unified patterns from the React ecosystem into a single, composable API.

options.text: From react-future, render props, DisplayScript, Rx, and ReasonReact
Invented from scratch with no prior art

title: How do you access imperative API of web components?
content: Use a `ref` to get the DOM node and call its methods directly, or wrap the web component in a React component for better integration.
explanation: Web components often expose methods like `focus()` or `play()` that must be called imperatively via refs.
sampleAnswers: Use `const wcRef = useRef();` and `<my-element ref={wcRef} />`, then call `wcRef.current.myMethod()`.
For better React integration, create a wrapper component that manages the web component’s state and props.

title: What is Formik?
content: Formik is a small React form library that handles form state, validation, and submission.
explanation: It solves the three main form problems: getting values in/out of state, validation, and submission handling.
sampleAnswers: Formik provides a minimal API to manage form state, validate inputs, and handle submission without Redux.
It uses render props or hooks to give you access to values, errors, and helpers like `handleChange` and `handleSubmit`.

title: What are typical middleware choices for async calls in Redux?
content: Popular choices: Redux Thunk, Redux Saga, and Redux Promise.
explanation: These middleware enable side effects like API calls in Redux’s otherwise pure action-reducer flow.

options.text: Redux Thunk, Redux Saga, Redux Promise
Middleware is not needed for async

title: Do browsers understand JSX code?
content: No. JSX must be transpiled to `React.createElement()` calls using Babel or similar tools.
explanation: Browsers only understand standard JavaScript; JSX is syntactic sugar transformed at build time.

title: Describe data flow in React?
content: React uses one-way data flow: data flows down from parent to child via props, making the data flow predictable and easier to debug.
explanation: Parents pass data to children via props; children communicate back via callback functions.
sampleAnswers: Data flows unidirectionally: parent components pass data to children via props, and children trigger updates by calling parent-provided callbacks.
This contrasts with two-way binding (e.g., AngularJS), where child changes automatically update parent state.

title: What is MobX?
content: MobX is a state management library that uses observable state and reactive programming to automatically update UI when state changes.
explanation: It tracks which components depend on which state and re-renders them automatically when that state changes.
sampleAnswers: MobX makes state observable and automatically re-renders components that use that state—no need for explicit selectors or reducers.
It’s often described as 'transparent reactivity'—you mutate state directly, and the UI updates magically.

title: What are the differences between Redux and MobX?
content: Redux: single store, immutable, explicit updates. MobX: multiple stores, mutable, automatic updates via observables.
explanation: Redux is explicit and predictable; MobX is implicit and automatic. Redux scales better for large teams; MobX is simpler for small apps.

options.text: Redux uses observables; MobX uses reducers
Redux: single immutable store, explicit; MobX: multiple mutable stores, automatic

title: Should I learn ES6 before learning ReactJS?
content: Not required, but helpful. React ecosystem heavily uses ES6 features like destructuring, spread operator, and arrow functions.
explanation: You can learn React without ES6, but most tutorials and codebases assume ES6 knowledge.

title: What is Concurrent Rendering?
content: Concurrent Rendering allows React to interrupt long renders to handle high-priority updates (e.g., user input), improving responsiveness.
explanation: It enables interruptible rendering, so the UI stays responsive during heavy updates.
sampleAnswers: Concurrent Rendering lets React pause and resume work based on priority—e.g., user clicks are handled before finishing a low-priority background render.
It’s the foundation for features like Suspense and automatic batching.

title: What is the difference between async mode and concurrent mode?
content: They are the same. 'Async Mode' was the old name; 'Concurrent Mode' is the current name to emphasize priority-based rendering.
explanation: The name changed to avoid confusion with other async patterns and to highlight the priority-based scheduling.

title: Can I use javascript URLs in React 16.9?
content: Yes, but it logs a warning because `javascript:` URLs are a security risk (XSS). Future versions will throw an error.
explanation: React warns against `javascript:` URLs to prevent accidental injection of malicious code.

title: What is the purpose of ESLint plugin for hooks?
content: It enforces the Rules of Hooks: (1) call hooks at top level, (2) call hooks only from React functions.
explanation: The plugin prevents bugs by ensuring hooks are called consistently across renders.
sampleAnswers: The `eslint-plugin-react-hooks` enforces that hooks are called in the same order every render and only from function components or custom hooks.
It also includes `exhaustive-deps` to validate effect dependencies.

title: What is the difference between Imperative and Declarative in React?
content: Imperative: how to do it (step-by-step DOM manipulation). Declarative: what the UI should look like (describe state, React handles updates).
explanation: React is declarative: you describe the UI for a given state, and React handles the DOM updates.
sampleAnswers: Imperative: 'If liked, remove grey class and add blue class.' Declarative: 'If liked, render <BlueLike />; else render <GreyLike />.'
Declarative code is easier to reason about because it separates 'what' from 'how'.

title: What are the benefits of using TypeScript with ReactJS?
content: Benefits: type safety, better IDE support, easier refactoring, interfaces for props/state, and fewer runtime errors.
explanation: TypeScript catches errors at compile time and provides excellent autocomplete and navigation in editors like VS Code.

options.text: Type safety, IDE support, fewer bugs, better refactoring

title: How to keep user authenticated on page refresh with Context API?
content: Call `loadUser()` in `useEffect` in App.js, ensuring the AuthProvider wraps the entire app in index.js to persist auth state across refreshes.
explanation: On page load, check for a token in storage and validate it to restore the user session.
sampleAnswers: Wrap your app in an AuthProvider in index.js. In App.js, use `useEffect` to call `loadUser()`, which checks localStorage/sessionStorage for a token and validates it with the backend.
This ensures the user remains logged in after refresh, similar to how Redux would handle it with a root-level dispatch.

title: What are the benefits of new JSX transform?
content: Benefits: (1) no need to import React, (2) slightly smaller bundles, (3) simpler mental model for beginners.
explanation: The new transform compiles JSX to `_jsx()` calls from `react/jsx-runtime`, removing the need for React in scope.

options.text: No React import needed, smaller bundles, simpler learning

title: How is the new JSX transform different from old transform?
content: Old: compiles to `React.createElement()`, requires `import React`. New: compiles to `_jsx()` from `react/jsx-runtime`, no React import needed.
explanation: The new transform reduces boilerplate and bundle size by using a dedicated runtime.
sampleAnswers: Old: `import React from 'react';` and `<div />` → `React.createElement('div')`. New: no import needed; `<div />` → `_jsx('div', {})`.
You still need to import React to use Hooks, but not for JSX alone.

title: What are React Server Components?
content: React Server Components render on the server, allowing direct data fetching and reducing client bundle size. Still experimental.
explanation: They enable zero-bundle-size components that run only on the server, with automatic client hydration for interactivity.
sampleAnswers: React Server Components run on the server, can access databases directly, and send only JSON to the client—reducing JavaScript bundle size.
They’re a key part of Next.js App Router and the future of React full-stack architecture.

title: What is prop drilling?
content: Prop drilling is passing data through multiple levels of components that don’t need it, just to get it to a deeply nested child.
explanation: It makes components tightly coupled and hard to refactor. Solutions: Context API or state management libraries.
sampleAnswers: Prop drilling occurs when you pass a prop through many intermediate components that don’t use it, just to reach a deep child.
This creates unnecessary dependencies. Use Context or Redux to avoid it.

title: What is the difference between useState and useRef hook?
content: `useState` triggers re-renders on update; `useRef` holds a mutable value without causing re-renders.
explanation: `useRef` is for persisting values across renders without triggering updates—ideal for timers, intervals, or DOM references.

options.text: useState causes re-renders; useRef does not
useRef is only for DOM elements

title: What is a wrapper component?
content: A wrapper component surrounds other components to add functionality, styling, or layout without modifying the wrapped components.
explanation: It’s a form of composition that promotes reuse and separation of concerns.
sampleAnswers: A wrapper component adds behavior or UI around children—e.g., a `Card` component that adds padding and a border.
Example: `<AuthWrapper><Profile /></AuthWrapper>` could check authentication before rendering the child.

title: What are the differences between useEffect and useLayoutEffect?
content: `useEffect` runs after browser paint; `useLayoutEffect` runs synchronously before paint, avoiding visual flicker for layout measurements.
explanation: Use `useLayoutEffect` only when you need to measure or adjust layout before the user sees it.

options.text: useEffect runs before paint; useLayoutEffect after
useEffect runs after paint; useLayoutEffect runs before paint synchronously

title: What are the differences between Functional and Class Components?
content: Functional: simpler syntax, use Hooks for state/effects. Class: use lifecycle methods, `this.state`, and `this.props`. Both can use state and props now.
explanation: With Hooks, functional components can do everything class components can, with less boilerplate.

options.text: Functional use Hooks; Class use lifecycle methods and this

title: What is strict mode in React?
content: `React.StrictMode` enables additional development-only checks for potential problems like unsafe lifecycles, legacy APIs, and side effects.
explanation: It helps catch bugs early by identifying unsafe patterns and legacy code.
sampleAnswers: `StrictMode` is a development tool that warns about deprecated APIs, unsafe lifecycle methods, and side effects in render.
It only runs in development and has no effect in production builds.

title: What is the benefit of strict mode?
content: Benefits: detects impure renders, missing effect cleanup, unsafe lifecycles, legacy refs/context, and findDOMNode usage.
explanation: It prepares your code for future React features like concurrent rendering by enforcing purity.

options.text: Detects side effects, unsafe lifecycles, legacy APIs, and missing cleanup

title: Why does strict mode render twice in React?
content: In development, StrictMode renders components twice to detect accidental side effects in the render phase by exposing non-idempotent code.
explanation: This double-invocation helps ensure components are pure and safe for concurrent features.
sampleAnswers: StrictMode calls render and effect functions twice in development to reveal side effects that rely on single execution.
This prepares apps for concurrent rendering, where React may interrupt or re-run renders.

title: What are the rules of JSX?
content: Rules: (1) return single root element, (2) all tags must be closed, (3) use camelCase for attributes (e.g., `className`).
explanation: These rules ensure JSX can be reliably transformed to JavaScript function calls.

options.text: Tags don't need to be closed
Single root, closed tags, camelCase attributes

title: What is the reason behind multiple JSX tags to be wrapped?
content: JSX compiles to JavaScript function calls, and a function can only return one value—so multiple elements must be wrapped in a parent or Fragment.
explanation: Without a wrapper, the transpiler would produce invalid JavaScript (multiple return values).
sampleAnswers: JSX is compiled to `React.createElement()` calls, and a function can only return one value—so multiple elements need a common parent.
React 16+ introduced Fragments (`<>...</>`) to avoid unnecessary DOM wrappers.

title: How do you prevent mutating array variables?
content: Avoid mutation methods (`push`, `pop`, `sort`, `reverse`). Use non-mutating methods (`map`, `filter`, `slice`) or spread syntax to create new arrays.
explanation: React and Redux rely on immutability to detect changes via reference comparison.
sampleAnswers: Instead of `arr.push(item)`, use `[...arr, item]`. Instead of `arr.sort()`, use `[...arr].sort()`.
Non-mutating methods like `map` and `filter` return new arrays, preserving immutability for state updates.

title: What are capture phase events?
content: Capture phase events (e.g., `onClickCapture`) fire during the downward phase of event propagation, before the target and bubbling phases.
explanation: They’re useful for analytics or global handlers that need to run before child event handlers.
sampleAnswers: `onClickCapture` fires from root to target during the capture phase, even if child events call `stopPropagation()`.
Order: capture handlers (top-down) → target handler → bubble handlers (bottom-up).
